text: Seventy-ninth session
Agenda item 157
Financing of the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic
Budget for the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic for the period from 1 July 2025 to 30 June 2026
Report of the Secretary-General
Contents
Mandate and planned results
A.	Overall

The mandate of the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (MINUSCA) was established by the Security Council in its resolution 2149 (2014). The most recent extension of the mandate was authorized by the Council in its resolution 2759 (2024), by which the Council extended the mandate until 15 November 2025.

The Mission is mandated to help the Security Council to advance a multi-year strategic vision to create political, security and institutional conditions conducive to national reconciliation and durable peace through the implementation of the Political Agreement for Peace and Reconciliation in the Central African Republic (the Political Agreement) and the elimination of the threat posed by armed groups through a comprehensive approach and proactive and robust posture, without prejudice to the basic principles of peacekeeping.

Within this overall objective, and reflecting the expanded mandate on electoral support, MINUSCA will, during the budget period, contribute to a number of expected accomplishments by delivering related key outputs, presented in the frameworks below. These frameworks are organized according to four components: support for political, peace and reconciliation processes; security, protection of civilians and human rights; fight against impunity and support for the extension of State authority and rule of law; and support, which are derived from the mandate of the Mission.

In its resolution 2759 (2024), the Council decided that MINUSCA would comprise an authorized troop ceiling of 14,400 military personnel, including 580 military observers and military staff officers, and 3,020 police personnel, including 600 individual police officers and 2,420 formed police unit personnel, as well as 108 corrections officers, and recalled its intention to keep that number under continuous review. In the same resolution, the Council mandated the Mission to continue the protection of civilians, support for the restoration and extension of State authority, and the peace and political process, including national reconciliation, social cohesion and transitional justice mechanisms. The Mission will also continue to facilitate a secure environment for the immediate, full, safe and unhindered delivery of humanitarian assistance and the protection of United Nations personnel and property.

The Council further authorized MINUSCA, working in close coordination with the United Nations country team, to support the preparation and delivery of free, fair and peaceful local, presidential and legislative elections scheduled in 2025 and 2026, in a transparent, credible, peaceful and timely manner.

The expected accomplishments would lead to the fulfilment of the objectives of the Security Council within the anticipated lifetime of the Mission, and the indicators of achievement will measure progress towards such accomplishments during the budget period. The human resources of MINUSCA in terms of the number of personnel have been attributed to the individual components, with the exception of the executive direction and management of the Mission, which is attributed to the Mission as a whole. Variances in the number of personnel, compared with the approved budget for the 2024/25 period, are explained under the respective components.

The MINUSCA headquarters and logistics base are located in Bangui and will support a total of 158 sites in 46 locations across the country. Mission locations comprise 12 field locations, including Bangui, with civilian, military and police units.
B.	Planning assumptions and mission support initiatives

MINUSCA remains committed to advancing its political strategy and integrated mission plan for the period 2023–202 In the context of anticipated challenges, the Mission will remain focused on enhancing its effectiveness through strengthened integration, coordination and decentralization.

In line with the request made by the Government of the Central African Republic on 28 February 2024 for United Nations electoral assistance, and as mandated by the Security Council, MINUSCA will prioritize supporting national stakeholders in the creation of conditions conducive to free, fair and inclusive rounds of elections during the 2025/26 period. This includes facilitating the preparation and conduct of the local elections and presidential and legislative elections, including preparation of necessary contingency plans. These elections are vital to advancing the Political Agreement and represent a significant step towards strengthening peace and stability in the Central African Republic by promoting democratic governance and expanding political participation for women, youth, internally displaced persons and returnees, while ensuring the timely renewal of political mandates in line with constitutional requirements. MINUSCA, in a whole-of-mission effort, will concentrate on facilitating the electoral processes, promoting dialogue, reducing tensions and supporting inclusive participation while providing operational, logistical, security and technical assistance in close coordination with the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and other international partners regarding international electoral assistance ensuring clear roles and responsibilities, with the support of the United Nations Resident Coordinator.

In line with the revised calendar for the holding of local elections issued by the National Electoral Authority in October 2024, the revision of the voter list is assumed to be completed by the end of March 2025. The local elections are anticipated to take place in July 2025, while the presidential and legislative elections are expected to occur between late December 2025 and mid-February 2026, in accordance with constitutional timelines. Preparations for the presidential and legislative elections are expected to commence after the conclusion of the local elections. Accordingly, the proposed budget for the 2025/26 period includes provisions amounting to $18,775,500 to support the local, presidential and legislative elections, as follows:
(Thousands of United States dollars)

As electoral dynamics are expected to dominate the period, potentially affecting the peace and security landscape, the Mission’s political role will continue to be vital, requiring the proactive use of good offices and political engagement to create the conditions for continued progress, including at the local level in key strategic areas. The Mission will intensify its efforts to promote the peace process through a decentralized approach supporting national institutions in enhancing ownership of implementation of the Political Agreement and its monitoring mechanisms. This involves building trust among national stakeholders, providing platforms for political dialogue and reconciliation, supporting the democratic process, and human rights and rule of law-compliant institutions and processes.

The Mission will also continue to support the Special Criminal Court and advocate for the promulgation of a Truth, Justice, Reparation and Reconciliation Commission mandate, as well as its operationalization as a key transitional justice mechanism recommended by the Political Agreement. In addition, it will work to strengthen grassroots reconciliation initiatives. These efforts are expected to capitalize on ongoing reconciliation efforts and build popular trust in national institutions. MINUSCA will leverage its strengthened integrated field presence to sustain, decentralize and enhance the country’s peace architecture and connections between the peace process at the national, regional and local levels in coordination with the Government, the United Nations country team and international partners.

MINUSCA will also continue to facilitate the implementation of the Political Agreement by supporting the national disarmament, demobilization, repatriation and reintegration programme, complemented by community violence reduction initiatives following integrated stabilization missions in key strategic areas. Special attention will be given to women participating in training programmes, in line with the national community violence reduction strategy. Further, the Mission will enhance the implementation of the security provisions outlined in the Political Agreement by providing policy, governance-focused and gender-sensitive advice, as well as technical and logistical support for the national security sector reform process. This will include intensified measures to secure and manage priority border areas, strategic advisory services, capacity-building initiatives and targeted assistance focused on the sustainable redeployment of national defence and internal security forces. All activities will be aimed at fostering democratic oversight and adherence to human rights principles, including compliance with the human rights due diligence policy.

MINUSCA will strengthen its political role through a proactive security strategy that integrates military and police components to create a secure environment that supports the peace process, protects civilians and upholds human rights, including during the electoral period. The Mission will concentrate on securing transhumance corridors and enhancing the internal security forces while empowering local stakeholders to peacefully resolve conflicts through comprehensive operational intelligence. In addition, MINUSCA will strengthen the capacity of Judicial Police Officers on transhumance law to address impunity and assess the deployment of internal security forces to mitigate inter-community violence.

To address explosive ordnance threats, the Mission will enhance monitoring efforts and provide life-saving risk education to vulnerable communities. Recognizing the potential for armed groups to expand their influence, MINUSCA will assist the Government of the Central African Republic in fostering relations with neighbouring countries, tackling cross-border criminality and promoting social cohesion. The Mission will employ integrated interventions to reduce threats of physical violence against civilians and support State authority in priority regions such as Vakaga, Haute-Kotto and Haut-Mbomou. These stabilization efforts will be complemented by logistical and institutional capacity support for relevant ministries and local authorities, ensuring the sustainable extension of the rule of law and governance for the population of the Central African Republic.

The Mission will enhance the mobility of uniformed components and improve its integrated field presence in priority areas, in line with the recommendations of the 2023 comprehensive logistics transportation assessment. This will involve the use of air assets, the concentration of forces, the optimization of operating bases and the construction or rehabilitation of airstrips, roads, bridges and ferries repositioning key enablers as part of the decentralization plan.

The mission-wide strategy on the protection of civilians will reinforce community-level dialogue and engagement, early warning and rapid response, and proactive security to address protection concerns and build national capacities. The Mission will continue to monitor and report on human rights violations, including conflict-related sexual violence and grave violations against children, while supporting national authorities in combating impunity and ensuring accountability. Furthermore, the Mission will support the safe transfer of children associated with armed groups to civilian authorities, in line with handover protocols, and will operationalize training centres to provide skills training and prevent child recruitment in conflict-affected areas. In line with the mandate, the budget proposal includes provisions for technical and logistical support for national defence and internal security forces engaged in joint operations with MINUSCA.

Despite improvements in security conditions in parts of the country, the humanitarian situation is expected to remain fragile owing to the continued socioeconomic hardship of large parts of the population. Improved security is anticipated to result also in an increased return of both internally displaced persons and refugees, which may exacerbate the needs of communities, and will challenge the economic recovery process by straining the State service delivery capacity. The instability observed in neighbouring countries, particularly in the Sudan, may precipitate an influx of refugees in inaccessible northern and eastern areas of the country. In response, the Mission will continue to support the safe delivery of humanitarian aid within its capacities and available resources, as well as through infrastructure projects, including the rehabilitation and construction of roads and bridges on main supply routes to improve access, support Mission operations and facilitate humanitarian assistance.

The Mission will intensify its collaboration with the United Nations country team and other humanitarian actors to create a protective environment through its good offices and advocacy at both the national and local levels, including regular security patrols and multifaceted community engagement, aiding the provision of assistance and supporting the voluntary, safe and durable return or resettlement of internally displaced persons and refugees. These efforts will embody a coordinated United Nations-wide response that will play a pivotal role in supporting the country’s long-term stability and development.

The sustainable extension and restoration of State authority will remain vital for safeguarding the Mission’s progress under its peace and protection mandates, including the gradual transition of static security tasks from MINUSCA to national defence and internal security forces. The Mission will continue to offer integrated operational, logistical and institutional support to national defence forces, adhering strictly to the human rights due diligence policy. MINUSCA will also continue to support the deployment of justice and penitentiary personnel to locations outside of Bangui as well as to provide internal oversight mechanisms in the justice and penitentiary systems to curb corruption and absenteeism.

MINUSCA will pursue efforts aimed at empowering the office for national security sector reform coordination, including with a view to better aligning international assistance with national needs and priorities. In addition, the Mission will continue to support the implementation of the national defence policy, facilitating the establishment of a garrison army, which will be instrumental in restoring security and State authority across the country. The Mission will continue to enhance the capacity of the General Inspectorate of the National Army to exercise its oversight function.

Furthermore, MINUSCA will continue to support the strengthening of the justice system, including through support for the ordinary justice system in the organization of criminal sessions for the trial of serious crimes and support for competent judicial bodies to address electoral disputes. MINUSCA will also continue to provide technical, logistical, financial and organizational support to the Special Criminal Court and the justice and penitentiary systems to address prison overcrowding and prolonged detention. MINUSCA will also continue to implement projects aimed at improving detention conditions and deliver capacity-building activities for all actors in the criminal justice system. The Mission will also support the Government in the implementation of the law on legal aid.

The illicit proliferation of small arms and light weapons is expected to continue and to pose a threat to peace and security. MINUSCA will continue to support the National Commission to Combat the Proliferation and Illegal Movement of Small Arms and Light Weapons, offering strategic, technical and logistical assistance in line with the objectives outlined in the National Commission’s national action plan for 2024–2028. In addition, the weapons and ammunition management capacities of the national defence and internal security forces will be further developed, including training and logistical support for managing and disposing of weapons and ammunition.

The Mission will continue to offer training to Mission personnel across the country and support predeployment visits to contributing countries, to uphold the United Nations zero-tolerance policy on sexual exploitation and abuse. Efforts to reduce sexual exploitation and abuse will be sustained through the appointment of focal points, the conduct of regular inspections and the integration of police and civilian staff with military units. In addition, the Mission will support victims of sexual exploitation and abuse through referral to existing service providers for medical care, psychosocial support, legal assistance, livelihood support and vocational training. MINUSCA will also continue to monitor the delivery and impact of these services and ensure that victims’ rights are upheld in collaboration with relevant partners.

To ensure the safety and security of United Nations personnel and assets, the Mission will bolster efforts to protect its staff and improve peacekeeper security. This will include an ongoing focus on enhancing mobility, force and camp protection, and living conditions, especially in the field. Efforts will also target improvements in aviation, critical for mobility, including capabilities for casualty and medical evacuation. In addition, technical support will be provided to national authorities to investigate and prosecute those responsible for crimes against peacekeepers.

The Mission has made significant strides in digital transformation and will continue to enhance this progress through the integrated use of tools such as Umoja for strategic planning, budgeting, and performance management; the strategic management application module; the integrated planning and reporting solution; and the Comprehensive Planning and Performance Assessment System. Efforts will continue to be focused on aligning all frameworks within these tools to optimize planning. These resources will support the implementation and monitoring of the Mission’s political strategy and integrated mission plan. MINUSCA will continue to regularly evaluate the effectiveness and impact of its political strategy and integrated mission plan for the period 2023–2028, identifying best practices and areas for improvement, in full cooperation with the United Nations country team and other partners for a comprehensive approach as defined in the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework. Furthermore, the Mission will leverage data and analysis from Umoja and its complementary systems to illustrate their impact and challenges.

The comprehensive communications and outreach strategy of the Mission, including its continued support for the Ministry of Communications and national communication initiatives, will be focused on enhancing the visibility of MINUSCA and keeping the public informed about its strategic priorities and impartial role, particularly in the electoral context. The Mission will engage in proactive strategic communications to counter misinformation and disinformation and hate speech. This will be combined with strengthened media monitoring, especially during electoral periods. MINUSCA will also improve survey methodology to gain deeper insights into public perceptions, thus informing more effective decision-making.

MINUSCA will strengthen its positive legacy strategy by fostering a political framework that is sustainable, supports the humanitarian-development-peace nexus and remains fully aligned with the national development plan. This approach will acknowledge past achievements while charting a clear path for the future. The Mission will reduce its environmental impact and support national renewable energy initiatives in line with the United Nations environmental strategy for peace operations. In addition, MINUSCA will concentrate on the gradual transfer of institutional knowledge to local stakeholders and on enhancing capacity-building, including boosting income-generating activities. Improvements to the country’s infrastructure, primarily aimed at supporting mandate implementation and ensuring civilian protection, will offer lasting benefits beyond the Mission’s duration, contributing to its legacy through close collaboration with the United Nations country team and multilateral partners.
Mission support initiatives

MINUSCA plans to implement its political strategy, including the decentralization of operations and the execution of construction projects aligned with the new force and police layouts, as well as initiatives aimed at enhancing the living and working conditions of Mission personnel, while carefully managing the ongoing cash liquidity challenges.

To support the decentralization and integration of field operations in the context of the implementation of new force and police layouts, planned infrastructure projects will include: (a) the construction of accommodation and aviation facilities in Bangassou; (b) the construction of new camps in Obo, Bambouti, Mboki, Am Dafok, Ouanda Djallé and Bangassou; (c) the construction of an aviation unit in Bangassou, including accommodation camps and helicopter landing pads; (d) the installation of a turnkey microgrid renewable energy system in M’Poko to upgrade and centralize the existing solar photovoltaic systems; (e) the rehabilitation and resurfacing of roads in Bangui; and (f) the construction of boreholes mission-wide.

The Mission will explore innovative solutions for water supplies in remote areas by utilizing atmospheric generators to provide water in temporary operating bases and other locations lacking alternative water sources. It will also increase the construction of hardwall buildings using locally available materials for accommodation and office space. This approach not only contributes to fulfilling the Mission’s commitment to sustainability but also leaves a positive legacy by increasing local employment opportunities and capacity-building and enhancing local procurement to foster economic stability.

The Mission’s supply chain systems will be improved to boost logistical efficiency and ensure dependable support throughout its operations. For this purpose, a decentralized warehousing approach will be implemented in regions with the highest demands, thus reducing lead times and overcoming transportation challenges. These investments will be bolstered by the digitalization of supply chain processes, including enhanced forecasting and risk monitoring. In addition, the Mission will maximize the use of a recently positioned C-130 Hercules aircraft to improve air cargo support. These initiatives are guided by recommendations from the Board of Auditors and the Office of Internal Oversight Services, as well as insights from the 2023 comprehensive logistics transportation assessment, which recommended the transition to a more efficient logistics model that leverages distribution hubs in Kaga Bandoro, Bangassou, Bambari and Bouar.

The Mission will continue its efforts to strengthen inventory and warehouse management through training, paying special attention on national capacity development, which in turn will improve demand forecasting and inventory accuracy and optimize transportation. In addition, through the deployment of monitoring systems, the Mission will ensure that logistics remain agile, resilient and capable of achieving results in fast-track decision-making processes.

Following the termination of the contract for the Mission’s unmanned aerial system in mid-2024, and acknowledging that no other capability can fully replace the system, MINUSCA will utilize the newly deployed Blackhawk UH-60 helicopters to conduct limited intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance operations.

MINUSCA will continue to implement its environmental strategy to mitigate its impact and reduce its overall footprint by increasing renewable energy capacity, refining energy management and enhancing solid and waste management. The Mission aims to diversify energy sources, including hydroelectricity, and connect to efficient grids and generators to reduce its reliance on diesel, cutting carbon emissions and fostering a positive legacy.

MINUSCA will continue to strengthen its information and communications technology systems, applications and infrastructure by: (a) making them more updated, integrated, resilient, agile and flexible in terms of service availability; (b) continuously strengthening the Mission’s infrastructure by replacing equipment that is beyond its life expectancy and is no longer supported by manufacturers; (c) continuing the migration of Mission data to the cloud (including servers and related services) as part of the Microsoft Azure authentication, and deploying the new cloud-based vehicle tracking system in Bangui and the regions; and (d) maintaining robust cybersecurity measures, including software updates for laptops, firewall and server updates/patching, and website filtering to protect the Mission against external cyberattacks.

To enhance operational effectiveness and to address in part the staffing gaps identified by the civilian staffing review conducted in MINUSCA in 2023, the Mission plans to outsource various high labour-content support services, including camp management, facility maintenance, warehousing operations, stock cycle counting and property physical verification. This approach will enable the Mission to leverage the expertise of specialized service providers, ensuring high-quality asset and maintenance management and the adoption of industry best practices and technologies.

The Mission will prioritize the development of a more structured training plan and the expansion of information and communications technology capabilities, in line with the Secretariat’s digital transformation strategy, strengthening data-driven decision-making through integrated information-sharing.

Beginning in the 2018/19 period, the Mission took a prudent approach to implementing the standardized mission support structure for field missions that was noted by the General Assembly in 2017 in its resolution 70/271. Subsequent changes in the Mission’s support structure were implemented through the realignment and/or redeployment of approved resources to strengthen and improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the component. The Mission will continue its efforts to align its support structure with the standardized approach during the 2025/26 period. The proposed changes are detailed in tables 12 to 24 of the present report.

The estimated resource requirements for the maintenance and operation of the Mission for the 2025/26 period reflect increased requirements under: (a) civilian personnel, attributable primarily to the application of lower vacancy rates, increased salary rates and higher common staff costs; and (b) operational costs, attributable primarily to the outsourcing of facilities maintenance and camp management services, including cleaning services, warehouse operations and physical verification services to enhance operational effectiveness and manage risks by leveraging the expertise of specialized service providers, and additional construction projects to support the decentralization and integration of field operations in the context of the implementation of new force and police layouts. The increased requirements are offset in part by reduced requirements under military and police personnel, attributable primarily to the planned deployment of less contingent-owned major equipment.
C.	Regional mission cooperation

The Mission will continue to liaise with the Global Procurement Support Section in Entebbe, Uganda, for the provision of commodities and services in support of mandate implementation. The Mission will also continue to use the logistics hub of the United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (MONUSCO), located in Entebbe, embedding one national General Service and two Field Service civilian personnel from MINUSCA to perform support functions related to administration, logistics and supply chain management.

The Regional Service Centre in Entebbe, Uganda, will continue to provide services to MINUSCA in the areas of onboarding and separation, benefits and payroll, vendor payments, entitlements and official travel, claims processing, including education grants and reimbursement for mission-related travel, cashier services, training and conference services, transport and movement control. In addition, MINUSCA will continue to use the United Nations Logistics Base at Brindisi, Italy, for stock deployment services, thereby optimizing procurement processes and enabling the timely delivery of mission supplies.
D.	Partnerships, country team coordination and integrated missions

To advance the implementation of the Political Agreement and support good governance, the Mission will prioritize coordination with the African Union, the Economic Community of Central African States, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, the European Union and other regional and international partners. MINUSCA will concentrate on enhancing interregional cooperation and leveraging synergies with regional missions such as the United Nations Regional Office for Central Africa (UNOCA) to improve collaboration, information-sharing, analysis and facilitation of peacebuilding efforts and conflict resolution initiatives. These partnerships are crucial for aligning strategic and organizational priorities to deliver unified and consistent support to national authorities, including post-electoral support.

To address transnational threats and promote stabilization and development in the Central African Republic, the Mission will continue to work closely with regional actors to implement joint bilateral commissions with neighbouring countries and ensure effective cross-border mechanisms, advancing the national policy for border area management developed in collaboration with UNOCA. Further, MINUSCA will continue to advocate for sustained engagement from neighbouring countries in the peace process and reconciliation efforts.

The Mission will maintain its collaboration with the United Nations country team, international financial institutions and other key stakeholders to advance a comprehensive approach that comprises humanitarian, human rights, development and peace initiatives. This includes bolstering support for the national human rights policy, the United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework for the period 2024–2027, the national strategy on lasting solutions for internally displaced persons and returnees and the national development plan for the Central African Republic for the period 2024–2028. The United Nations will continue to support the Government of the Central African Republic in delivering on the outputs of the national development plan and enhancing the communication of achievements and tangible peace dividends to the population.

The use of good offices and peacebuilding projects through the Peacebuilding Fund will continue to play a catalytic role in supporting the implementation of the Political Agreement, including the joint road map for peace in the Central African Republic, supporting the operationalization of the border management strategy and creating favourable conditions for credible, peaceful, inclusive and participatory local elections.

Human resources: Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General

The Office provides direction and guidance to all mission components to ensure that all mandated tasks are implemented in a coordinated manner. The Office leads the design, development and delivery of coherent strategic communication programmes with ownership by all Mission components. In addition, the Special Representative established under her immediate leadership the Mission’s mis- and disinformation working group to monitor and address threats to effective mandate delivery. Additional support is required to provide adequate assistance to the Special Representative in the performance of her strategic communication responsibilities within the context of the Mission’s response to misinformation and disinformation.

It is proposed that one post of Communications Officer (P-3) (formerly Radio Producer in the Strategic and Communications and Public Information Service), as shown in table 2, be reassigned from the Strategic Communications and Public Information Service. The reassigned post will enhance the Mission’s strategic communication programmes, carry out cross-pillar coordination and address misinformation and disinformation issues. It will also support the Office of the Special Representative and the Mission at large in developing and implementing global, comprehensive, coherent and coordinated responses to the threat of hate speech, stigmatization, misinformation and public incitement to violence within the context of mandate implementation.

It is also proposed that one post of Special Assistant, Political Affairs (P-4) be redeployed from the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General to the Office of the Chief of Staff, as the latter requires additional capacity in order to effectively support the coordination and management of operational tasks, including planning, decision-making and the integration of various Mission components that face the growing complexities and demands of the Mission’s operations. The incumbent will assist the Chief of Staff in ensuring the coherence and alignment of Mission activities across all units, while directly supporting the senior leadership of the Mission.

To that end, the Chief of Staff oversees the core mechanisms and processes that enable integrated delivery of the Mission’s mandate, in particular strategic and operational planning, policy coordination, senior-level decision-making and information management within the Mission and with the United Nations country team. The Office plays a central role in directing and managing the day-to-day running of the Mission, the management and oversight of programmatic funds and quick-impact projects, and the greater coordination among Mission components. It also facilitates effective integration and controls within Mission headquarters and field offices. The Office requires additional capacity to address an increased need for enhanced coordination and coherence across Mission components, as described below.

Human resources: Electoral Affairs Service

The Electoral Affairs Service is responsible for providing support for the local, legislative and presidential elections. The local elections are anticipated to take place in July 2025, while the presidential and legislative elections are expected to be held between late December 2025 and mid-February 2026, in accordance with constitutional timelines. The Mission seeks to retain its capacity to effectively support the National Electoral Authority at its headquarters and at the prefectural level. The Mission’s electoral support is outlined in paragraph 9 above, based on the mandate provided in Security Council resolution 2759 (2024).

To implement the Mission’s mandate, the continuation of the Electoral Affairs Service with 30 general temporary assistance positions and 37 United Nations Volunteer positions, as shown in table 8, is proposed. Under the leadership of a Principal Electoral Affairs Officer (D-1), the Service will continue to support the National Electoral Authority. The Service will also continue to ensure territorial coverage through the deployment of one Electoral Officer/Regional Coordinator, one Electoral Adviser (Logistics) and one Electoral Adviser (Civic and Voter Registration) in each of its field offices, covering the country’s 20 prefectures, who will consult with all electoral stakeholders and partners, including United Nations entities on the ground, and provide technical and logistical support for the local branches of the National Electoral Authority.

The Office assists and supports the Director of Mission Support in the effective management of support services in the Mission, including monitoring the level and quality of support services delivered to Mission headquarters and field office locations.

The implementation of a decentralized approach in the field in previous budget periods coupled with the planned movement of mission personnel from Bangui to the field will translate into an increased presence at those remote locations in difficult working and living conditions. A survey on mental health recently conducted at the Mission revealed the need to strengthen the management of Mission personnel’s well-being. The Mission will enhance its monitoring and control of operational activities to ensure the successful and timely delivery of a sustainable welfare strategy.

In the context of paragraph 39 of the present report, it is proposed that the Mission’s counselling and welfare portfolio, which includes three posts, as shown in table 13, be redeployed from the Human Resources Management Section to strengthen the oversight of counselling and welfare services delivery.

H.	Analysis of requirements for air operations

The flight-hour utilization rates for the periods from 2021/22 to 2023/24, the approved and proposed number of flight hours for the 2024/25 and 2025/26 periods, respectively, and the proposed number of flight hours calculated on the basis of the new policy guidance are as follows:

The Mission’s air assets for the 2025/26 period will include 7 fixed-wing and 14 rotary-wing aircraft, all fully deployed in the mission area. Over the years, there has been a significant improvement in the utilization rate of budgeted flight hours, increasing from 64 per cent in the 2018/19 period to 83.4 per cent in the 2023/24 period. Low utilization rates in prior periods were primarily attributable to: (a) delayed deployment of aircraft caused by delays in the acquisition process; (b) under-performance of military air assets due to extended maintenance periods and some assets that were not fit for purpose; and (c) delays in the electoral calendar. The proposed number of flight hours for the period 2025/26 is in line with the policy and inclusive of an additional 780 flight hours, which represent the additional requirements for the mission to support presidential and legislative elections as newly mandated by the Security Council in its resolution 2759 (2024).

The Mission’s approach to aircraft deployment focuses on maximizing operational efficiency and ensuring rapid response capabilities. During the 2024/25 period, the Mission has reconfigured its air assets by: (a) replacing a shared fixed-wing aircraft with a C-130 Hercules aircraft on a full-time basis; (b) increasing rotary-wing capability with the addition of one commercial helicopter; (c) upgrading the rotary-wing capability of one tactical military aviation unit by replacing three AB-205 helicopters with Black Hawk UH-60 helicopters, which offer multi-role capabilities better suited to the Mission’s requirements; and (d) replacing an Antonov 26 aircraft with a more versatile ATR-72 aircraft.

In the 2025/26 period, the Mission plans to reposition one military aviation unit from Bangui to the new sector in Bangassou to support the implementation of the new force and police layout in Sector East.

J.	Quick-impact projects
The estimated resource requirements for quick-impact projects for the period from 1 July 2025 to 30 June 2026, compared with previous periods, are as follows:
(Thousands of United States dollars)

Quick-impact projects will continue to act as a strategic tool that supports the implementation of the Mission’s political strategy and integrated mission plan by facilitating the creation of an enabling and conducive environment. This strategic vehicle improves the Mission’s credibility, builds trust and increases confidence in MINUSCA and in the political, peace and reconciliation process. Across the Central African Republic, quick-impact projects have been instrumental in aiding in the delivery of basic social services, thus alleviating the daily economic challenges faced by vulnerable communities that include returnees, in facilitating access through the construction and rehabilitation of bridges and ferries, and in the restoration of public administration through sustained investment.

All projects will be implemented in coordination with humanitarian organizations and development partners. Project identification will require the systematic inclusion of local authorities and community-based requests in the design and implementation of participatory projects, mainly targeting women and youth, minorities and vulnerable people in return zones and separation from armed groups in the reintegration process. Consistent with the quick-impact projects policy, projects will be identified through grass-roots participation, coordinated across mission components and sections, and in consultation with other national and international stakeholders and partners. Credible implementing partners will be identified and scrutinized by the local project review committees before being selected to deliver quality and sustainable projects in short-term durations. With the decentralized arrangement in place to support the vision of the Mission, 110 small-scale quick-impact projects will be implemented covering mainly the following three priority areas:

Support for the political, peace and reconciliation processes. Resources will contribute to (i) the timely delivery of social and economic services to the local administration in coordination with strategic partners’ investment; (ii) the timely delivery of livelihoods for the population in conjunction with the United Nations country team; (iii) support for investment in agriculture, health, water, electricity and education aimed at fostering development; and (iv) support for the operationalization of local-level peace and reconciliation and transitional justice mechanisms as well as support for inclusive and credible local elections by enhancing women’s participation in local elections;

Facilitation of the mobility of uniformed components and enhancement of the integrated field presence of MINUSCA in the protection of civilians. Projects will concentrate on the construction or rehabilitation of cross-border infrastructures and the repair of ferries to ease access to remote areas. The implementation of projects will allow for an adequate and timely response by the MINUSCA force, national and local authorities and national defence and internal security forces. The reinforcement of cross-border infrastructures and the rehabilitation of ferries will facilitate more military patrol missions and operations to prevent protection threats, facilitate humanitarian access, restore freedom of movement, promote conflict management and reduce violence towards women related to transhumance as well as allow the free movement of goods and population across the country. In coordination with the Mission’s uniformed personnel, national authorities and local and international non-governmental organizations, early warning mechanisms will be created or strengthened, and communication and coordination systems will be established to complement activities for the protection of civilians implemented by MINUSCA to improve communities’ capacities to organize themselves and be better linked to the MINUSCA protection system;

Support for the sustainable restoration and enhancement of State authority in the areas of security, rule of law, fight against impunity and local administration. Quick-impact projects will (i) support the deployment of national defence personnel and enhance respect for human rights and the rule of law; (ii) contribute towards the re-establishment of local State administration; (iii) advance criminal justice and the fight against impunity across the country; (iv) advance the demilitarization of prisons throughout the country; and (v) support the deployment of internal security forces and enhance respect for human rights and the rule of law through the construction and rehabilitation of public administrative and security services buildings and the provision of equipment.
